journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Effect of compression ratio and injection timing on the performance characteristics of a diesel engine running on palm oil methyl ester

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati, India

author-notes.corresp: Ujjwal K Saha, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati-781039, Assam, India. Email: saha@iitg.ernet.in

abstract.p: Diesel fuel has a limited resource, and concerns over environmental pollution are leading to the use of ‘bio-origin fuels’ as they are renewable and environmentally benign. Palm oil methyl ester, an esterified biofuel, has an excellent cetane number and a reasonable calorific value. Besides, palm oil methyl ester (C18.07H34.93O2) has around 11.25% of oxygen bonded in its molecular structure which increases its burning intensely. Thus, it closely resembles the behavior of diesel. However, being a fuel of different origin, the standard design limits of a diesel engine is not suitable for palm oil methyl ester. Therefore, in this work, a set of design and operational parameters are studied to find out the optimum performance of a palm oil methyl ester run diesel engine. The parameters varied are the compression ratio (CR) and injection timing (IT) along with load in a variable compression ratio diesel engine. The palm oil methyl ester run engine is investigated for its performance, combustion and emission characteristics. The combination of CR = 18 and IT = 20°BTDC improves the efficiency by 8% and cuts the exhaust gas temperature by 5%. Moreover, the palm oil methyl ester run engine lowers the ignition delay which further gets reduced by 7% and 12% with CR augmentation and IT retardation, respectively. The increase in CR trims down carbon monoxide by 40%, nitrogen oxides by 46% and hydrocarbon by 40%; however, it increases carbon dioxide emission by 19%. The IT retardation reduces the carbon dioxide emission by 16%.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Now-a-days, the socio-economic sculpture of the world is greatly influenced by the production, price and the use of petroleum fuels. In the first two months of the year 2011, the world has seen a US$100 of Brent crude price on the New York Mercantile Exchange which was 30% higher than the level at the start of December 2010.1 From 1980 to 2004, the oil consumption in 12 most petroleum exporting countries has increased so drastically that some of them have already become importer of oil in 2009 than exporter at way back 1999, namely Egypt, Indonesia, etc.2 Saudi Arabia, the largest producer of petroleum oil, has recorded an increase in oil usage of around 4% a year. This means, if it is unable to raise oil production upto 11 million barrels a day, its exports will disappear by 2050.1 These reasons have accelerated the progress of alternative fuels especially biodiesel. Currently, India consumes around 2.98 billion barrels of oil per day. Merely 7.5% of this measure is blended with biodiesel and is expected to increase around 10% at the end of 2012. At this moment, the biodiesel production in India is only 8% of its total capacity.3 Hence, there is an excellent scope for India to escape from this fossil fuel contrary, by producing, blending and utilizing biodiesel.

The concept of using vegetable oil as a fuel dates back to 1895 when Rudolf Diesel developed and ran his engine using peanut oil at the World Exhibition in Paris in 1900.4 ‘Biodiesels’ generally termed as methyl or ethyl esters are derived from vegetable oils. The use of vegetable oils and their methyl esters as diesel substitute has been extensively evaluated in many countries.5–7 A host of researchers have worked with Jatropha oil and its biodiesel in both diesel and dual-fuel engines.8–10 Agarwal and Rajamanoharan11 investigated the Karanja oil blending with diesel in diesel engine with and without preheating. The oxygenated biodiesels are used in diesel engines, which reduce emissions of total hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide (CO), oxides of sulfur (SOX), aromatic hydrocarbons, and carbonyl compounds.12–15 The vegetable oil such as crude palm oil is converted to esters, called palm oil methyl ester (POME), by combining the esterification and transesterification processes.16 Most of the investigations using POME in diesel engines are on the effect of POME blending with diesel.17–20 The emulsified POME blends result in lower particulate matter emission, improve energy-saving and cuts down the fuel consumption.21 The increase in volume of water in POME-diesel emulsion reduces carbon deposition on engine parts and also results in bigger fuel droplets and poor fuel air mixing. As a result, the fuel flammability drops, the combustion efficiency reduces showing an increase in CO emission. Simultaneously, the droplet size of the dispersed phase also plays a significant role in emulsified fuel combustion.22,23 The emulsified fuels provide lower oxides of nitrogen emissions. This is because of the water vaporization, which causes reduction in local temperature, inept nitrogen to get enough activation energy to react with oxygen to form oxides of nitrogen.24 The increase in POME in its blending with diesel has found to advance the timing of fuel injection. This is because in order to keep the same brake power (BP) and speed, the injection pump has to work a little early to inject more fuel. As a result, the energy release starts early and the peak combustion pressure rises to about 12 bar. POME has a calorific value a little lower than diesel, which causes the brake specific fuel consumption (BSFC) to increase for the same BP, thereby reducing the brake thermal efficiency.25,26 The higher altitude engine operation with POME shows an advanced fuel injection than that of sea level. Further, it requires a 12% increase of POME to compensate the lower heating value of biodiesel.27 Masjuki et al.28 studied several combinations of preheated POME and intake air conditions. The brake power (BP) produced by their engine improved at higher POME temperature of 95 °C and 50 °C along with intake air temperature at 35 °C. This is because a rise in POME temperature causes a reduction in viscosity, resulting in better fuel spray, atomization and fuel evaporation. This leads to an enhanced combustion thereby trimming down the oxides of carbon and hydrocarbon emissions. However, the specific fuel consumption is found to increase owing to a fall in viscosity and an increase in fuel supply. This fact outshines the increase in power thereby reducing the efficiency, comparable to baseline diesel. Similarly Almeida et al.29 also worked with preheated palm oil in a diesel engine. They also found to have both higher fuel consumption and increased carboniferous emission.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p:
The review of literature on POME run diesel engines confirms that the mechanical, combustion and emission characteristics of POME run engine under variable compression ratio (CR) and injection timing (IT) are not transparent till now. In view of this, the present study focuses on the behavior of a diesel engine, run with 100% POME for a set of CR and IT variation. The CRs are varied from 16 to 17, 17.5 and 18, where ITs are set at 20°, 23° and 28° before top dead center (BTDC). Thus, a total of 12 combinations of CR and IT are prepared for checks. The variations of load are performed from no-load to full-load (4.14 bar BMEP) with an increment of 0.83 bar BMEP (20%) as presented in the experimental matrix (Table 1). Here, the baseline diesel specification considered is CR of 17.5 and IT of 23°BTDC and is used for comparison with the findings with POME run engine. The performance analyses evaluated are brake thermal efficiency (BTHE), brake specific fuel consumption (BSFC) and exhaust gas temperature (EGT). The combustion analyses include the cylinder pressure variation, ignition delay (ID), peak cylinder pressure (PCP) and net heat release rate (NHRR). Finally, emission analysis is performed by measuring carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), oxides of nitrogen (NOX) and hydrocarbon (HC). Table 1.
The experimental matrix for POME in VCR engine.
Load – BMEP (bar) Injection timing (°BTDC)
20 23 28
0 (No load), 0.83 (20%), 1.65 (40%), 2.48 (60%), 3.31 (80%), 4.14 (100%) CR(POME) = 16 Diesel (CR = 17.5) CR(POME) = 16
CR(POME) = 17 CR(POME) = 16 CR(POME) = 17
CR(POME) = 17.5 CR(POME) = 17 CR(POME) = 17.5
CR(POME) = 18 CR(POME) = 17.5 CR(POME) = 18
CR(POME) = 18
VCR: variable compression ratio; POME: palm oil methyl ester; BMEP: brake mean effective pressure; BTDC: before top dead center; CR: compression ratio.

sec.title: The engine test bed
sec.p:
The experiments are executed in a direct injection, water-cooled variable compression ratio (VCR) diesel engine (Figure 1). Table 2 illustrates the specifications of the engine. The CR is varied by tilting the cylinder head with a CR adjuster nut without stopping the engine and without altering the combustion chamber geometry. The water-cooled dynamometer, equipped with the engine, apply load on crank shaft with the help of electromagnetic force. A regulator, mounted on the panel box, controls electric supply for load variation. A load sensor, equipped with the dynamometer, transfers the load signal to the digital display in kilograms. The instrumentation for combustion pressure and crank-angle measurements are provided in the setup. The signals are interfaced to the computer through an engine indicator for pressure-crank angle (P–θ) and pressure–volume (P–V) diagrams for the 360° rotation of the crank. Provisions are also made to quantify airflow, fuel flow, exhaust gas temperatures and load measurements. The thermocouples used in this work have a response time more than 0.08 s (for the 1500 r/min constant speed engine). Hence, they cannot show the pulsation nature of the exhaust gas in the form of temperature readings and are found almost steady after a certain time (nearly 5 min) at a particular load. The stand-alone panel box, embedded with the setup, consists of an air box, a fuel tank, a manometer, a fuel measuring unit, transmitters for air and fuel flow measurements, a process indicator and an engine indicator. Rotameters measure the engine and the calorimeter water flow. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of the VCR engine setup.
VCR: variable compression ratio.
Table 2.
The brief specifications of VCR diesel engine.
Parameter Specification
Engine type Research engine test set up
General details 1 cylinder, 4 stroke, VCR, water cooled diesel engine
Rated output 3.5 kW at 1500 r/min
Bore and stroke 87.5 mm × 110 mm
Capacity 661 cc
Compression ratio 17.5 (range 12–18)
Fuel injection system Pump-line-nozzle (injection pressure 250–300 bar)
Injection timing 23°BTDC (range 0–30°BTDC)
Dynamometer Eddy current loading unit, 0–12 kg
Cylinder and fuel pressure sensors Piezo sensor, range: 5000 psi,
Resolution: 0.1 psi, sensitivity: 1 mv/psi
Temperature sensors PT100, range 0–100°C, output 4–20 mA (4 nos)
K type, range 0–1200°C, output 4–20 mA (2 nos)
Fuel flow transmitter Differential pressure transmitter, Calibration range: 0–500 mm H2O
Air flow transmitter Pressure transmitter, range: (-) 250 mm of water column
VCR: variable compression ratio; BTDC: before top dead center.

sec.title: Measurement of emission
sec.p:
The emission measurement is carried out by a Testo flue gas analyzer. The analyzer follows ASTM-D6522 emission measurement standard. The instrument calibrates automatically by measuring oxygen quantity in the air, each time it is restarted. During steady-state engine operation, the flue gas is allowed to surge through a probe followed by a condensation trap to dry out the gas. The flue gas analyzer analyzes the samples and displays the relevant concentrations of CO, NOX, CO2 and HC emissions on the control unit. CO and NOX are measured through electrochemical measurement cells, where CO2 and HC are measured by Infrared and Pellistor Heat Affect Detector, respectively. The resolution, accuracy and range of these emission parameters are shown in Table 3.30 Table 3.
The specifications of Testo 350 S/M/XL flue gas analyzer.
S. No. Measured gas Resolution Accuracy Range
1 CO 1 ppm ±10 ppm < 200 ppm 0–10,000 ppm
±5% reading < 2000 ppm
±10% reading > 2000 ppm
2 CO2 0.01 vol.% < 25% ±0.3 vol.%. < 25% 0–50%
0.1 vol.% > 25% ±0.5 vol.% > 25%
3 NO 1 ppm ±5 ppm < 100 ppm 0–3000 ppm
±5% reading < 2000 ppm
±10% reading > 2000 ppm
4 NO2 0.1 ppm ±5 ppm < 100 ppm 0–500 ppm
±5% reading > 100 ppm
5 HC 1 ppm 400 ppm < 4000 ppm 0–40,000 ppm
10% reading > 4000 ppm

sec.title: Test procedure
sec.p:
Initially, the engine is run with diesel to execute base line test. The standard setting (CR = 17.5 and IT = 23°BTDC) is maintained while operating the engine with diesel at constant speed of 1500 ± 50 r/min thorough out the load range. The water flow rates, necessary for the engine and calorimeter cooling are 280 and 80 L/h, respectively. The engine warms up after a few minutes run at no-load condition. The temperatures at the outlets of the cooling water and exhaust gas are monitored closely until it reaches the steady state. This indicates that the combustion inside the cylinder becomes stable and the engine is ready for data acquisition. Thereafter, the value of CR, water flow rate to the engine and calorimeter are entered manually in the software. The fuel measurement is performed for 1 min by regulating the fuel cork. The experimental observations at that load include temperatures, air and fuel flow rates; speed, cylinder and fuel pressure variations with crank angle are automatically sensed by the DAC and the performance parameters are calculated. The sample of flue gas is then allowed to pass through the Testo flue gas analyzer probe, which quantifies the amount of CO, CO2, NOX and HC emissions. Thereafter, the load level is increased as mentioned in the experimental matrix and the same processes as described above are repeated. This completes the total baseline test. Later, for the POME test, diesel oil is replaced by POME in the fuel tank. The engine is started with POME at standard diesel engine specifications and run for around 10 min to clear the entire diesel in the fuel line and to get steady. Necessary changes are made in the DAC software to provide the density and calorific value of the POME (Table 4). The experiments show that, IT advances by 0.5° to 1° from the standard one due to the change in the physical properties of POME. However, this minor change is corrected and the IT is brought back to the standard one to have a true comparison between diesel and POME run engines. Once the POME run engine reaches a steady-state condition, the processes described for baseline tests are repeated. After recording the data for one set of CR-IT combination, the engine is then brought back to no-load condition slowly and allowed to run for few minutes before shifting it to other CR setting.35 Once all the CRs for one IT are tested, the engine is then shifted to run at other ITs and the same procedure is repeated (Table 1) before a complete shutdown. Most of the experiments are performed at least three times and the averaged data are presented. All the experiments performed are within 27 ± 3 °C and atmospheric pressure conditions. Table 4.
The significant properties of diesel and POME.
Properties Diesel POME
Chemical composition C12H26 C18.07H34.93O2
Density (kg/m3)8 840 870
Lower heating value (MJ/kg)8 42 39.84
Cetane number31,32 45–55 50–65
Auto-ignition temperature (K)33 553 –
Stoichiometric air fuel ratio8 14.92 12.52
Energy density (MJ/Nm3)8 2.82 –
Viscosity (cst)34 4.59 5.22
Bulk modulus (MPa) at 1 bar25 ∼1400 ∼1600
POME: palm oil methyl ester.

sec.title: Analysis methodology
sec.p: The fundamental equations for calculating the dependent variables35 are as follows:

sec.title: Brake thermal efficiency (BTHE)
sec.p: (1)BTHE=[BP/(m·fuel×LHVfuel)]×100 where BP is the brake power of the engine in kW, m·fuel is the mass flow rate of fuel in kg/s and LHVfuel is the lower heating value of the fuel in kJ/kg.

sec.title: Brake specific fuel consumption (BSFC)
sec.p: (2)BSFC=[(m·fuel/BP)×3600] where BP is the brake power of the engine in kW, m·fuel is the mass flow rate of fuel in kg/s.

sec.title: Brake mean effective pressure (BMEP)
sec.p: (3)BMEP=(BP×60)/[(π/4)×D2×L×(N/n) ×K×100] where D is the bore diameter in m, L is the length of stroke in m, N is the engine shaft revolution in r/min, n is the number of complete revolutions of the crank shaft per cycle and K is the number of cylinders.

sec.title: Net heat release rate
sec.p: The NHRRs, calculated for both diesel and POME run engines, needs the instantaneous P–V data recorded during experiments. The crank angle encoder, connected to the engine shaft, detects each degree rotation of the crank for each cycle. Hence, for a particular cycle, a total of 720 data for both cylinder pressure and volume are recorded at each load and CR-IT combination. Therefore, to avoid annoying calculations of huge data, at least three cycles are considered for the purpose of heat release calculations at each load and each CR-IT combination. The equation used for the NHRR is obtained from the first law analysis by implementing rate of pressure rise and rate of volume change, which is given below.36–38 (4)dQn/dθ=[{γ/(γ-1)}×P×(dV/dθ)] +[{1/(γ-1)}×V×(dP/dθ)] where Qn is the net heat release rate in J/°CA, γ is the ratio of specific heats, P is the instantaneous cylinder pressure in N/m2, V the instantaneous volume of the cylinder in m3. The value of γ is taken as 1.35.36,38 The values of change of volume per unit change of crank angle (dV/dθ) are calculated from the instantaneous volume change data recorded during experiments. The values of change of pressure per unit change of crank angle (dP/dθ) are evaluated by using following first-order finite difference equation with fourth order accuracy.39 (5)dP/dθ=[(Pn-2)-8(Pn-1)+8(Pn+1) -(Pn+2)]/[12(Δθ)] where ‘Δθ’ is the successive change of crank angle in °CA. The raw cylinder pressure data traced by DAC is differentiated which shows a noisy trend amid successive values. Hence, after-treatment of pressure data in the form of smoothing is vital. The following equation is used for smoothing the instantaneous pressure data.39 (6)Pn=[(Pn-1)+2(Pn)+(Pn+1)]/4

sec.title: Ignition delay
sec.p: Ignition delay is the difference between the duration between the fuel IT (θIN) and the crank angle at which combustion starts (θIG).38 Therefore (7)θR=θIG-θIN

The standard fuel IT of 23°BTDC is obtained from the manufacturer’s specifications. The ITs, other than the standard one, are obtained from the fuel pressure data stored during data acquisition. These angles are confirmed by checking the maximum pressure point in fuel data with respect to angle change. The crank angle at which combustion starts is obtained from dP/dθ versus crank angle diagram by observing its concavity at the point of ignition.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The overall investigations performed in this work include the performance, combustion and emission characteristics of a POME run engine at various combinations of load, CR and IT. Hence, this novel study reveals the performance parameters of a diesel engine run by POME at different CRs and IT combinations. The experimental results are found closer to that of results available in literature.26,40

sec.title: Effect of load
sec.p:
The trends seen in Figure 2(a) to (c) show that the POME run engine provides a closer level of efficiencies to that of diesel. The POME run engine provides a maximum of 7% higher BTHE than diesel at 0.83 bar and 1.65 bar of BMEP. However, on and onwards 2.48 bar BMEP, BTHE of POME run engine is little lower than diesel. The reason is very clear from Figure 2(d) to (f) where BSFC are plotted against BMEP. The BSFCs, observed at 20° and 28°BTDC are lower than the same at 23°BTDC. However, on and onwards 2.48 bar BMEP; the BSFCs for POME run engine are increased for almost all the CR–IT combinations like diesel. With the increase in load, BSFCs for all the CR–IT combinations fall. The average values of BSFCs are 0.88, 0.43 and 0.35 kg/kW-h for 0.83 bar, 2.48 bar and 4.14 bar BMEP, respectively. Therefore, at highest load, BSFC of POME is about 51% lower than 0.83 bar BMEP. This is due to the decline of heat losses from the engine at higher loads. The EGT varies almost linearly with load as seen from Figure 3(a) to (c). The average EGTs increase from 132 °C at no-load condition to 259 °C at highest load with an average increase of 14.5% for each 20% rise of load. The same trend is observed for all the CR and IT combinations of the POME run engine. Figure 2.
Variation of brake thermal efficiency (a, b and c) and brake specific energy consumption (d, e and f) with engine load for different compression ratio and injection timing.
Figure 3.
Variation of exhaust gas temperature (a, b and c) with engine load for different compression ratio and injection timing.

sec.title: Effect of compression ratio
sec.p:
The maximum BTHEs for the POME run engine at various CRs and at standard IT of 23°BTDC are compared to that of the diesel engine in Figure 4(a). In all the cases, results are shown for the full-load. The rise in CR usually tends to increase BP.26 However, in this study, since the speed and the BP is maintained constant, the rise in CR reduces the BSFC. For the three IT studied (20°, 23° and 28°BTDC), the average rise in BTHEs are 7%, 5% and 3% respectively through CR increase from 16 to 18. This is because POME has some molecular oxygen bonded in its chemical composition (Table 4), which gets released at a faster rate in a high temperature environment at the end of compression stroke caused by a higher CR.19 Since POME has a higher consumption rate than diesel (Figure 2), the increase in CR from 16 to 18 has shown a drop in BSFC. The average reductions of BSFCs are 11%, 12% and 1% respectively, with the increase of CR from 16 to 18 for all the IT combinations studied. Being a little denser than diesel, POME performs more economically at higher CRs.41 In case of POME, the EGT is found to fall with the rise in CR as seen in Figure 3. An increase in CR from 16 to 17 shows a drop of the average EGT by 2%, where 3% and 4% reduction in EGT takes place with the increase in CR from 17 to 17.5 and 17.5 to 18, respectively. This is because higher CR increases the air temperature inside the cylinder. This ultimately reduces the ignition lag and hence ensures a more complete combustion. At no-load condition, the mean temperatures are 134 °C, 132 °C, 131 °C and 128 °C at CRs of 16, 17, 17.5 and 18, respectively. On the other hand, at full-load, these values are 274 °C, 263 °C, 255 °C and 243 °C, respectively. Thus, on the basis of EGT, the CR of 18 looks attractive. Figure 4.
(a) Comparison of maximum brake thermal efficiency with compression ratio at standard injection timing and (b) combined variation of compression ratio and injection timing.

sec.title: Effect of injection timing
sec.p: Figure 2(a) to (c) shows that a 3° retardation (from 23°BTDC to 20°BTDC) and a 5° advancement (from 23°BTDC to 28°BTDC) of POME injection results in a higher part-load efficiency than diesel. Figure 4(b) compares the peak values of BTHEs for the POME run engine at full-load for two higher CRs (17.5 and 18) and three ITs (20°, 23° and 28°BTDC). IT advancement increases the peak BTHEs by about 5% and 4% for the tested CRs of 17.5 and 18, respectively. However, retarding the IT has a major effect on maximum BTHEs which increase by about 9% and 7%, respectively. The average BTHEs at 20°, 23° and 28°BTDC are 17%, 15.79% and 16.6%, respectively. Thus, retarding the IT improves BTHE by 8% which is comparable to an increase of 5% while advancing. This is because of the incorrect matching of the PCP and MHRR point for 28°BTDC which is resolved by retarding the IT. Hence, 20°BTDC provides the most efficient burning for the POME run engine. The average drop in BSFC is 6% for IT advancement of 5°. Whereas, retarding the IT causes an average drop of BSFC by 8%. This is analogous and corroborates the effect of IT variation on the BTHE. At advanced IT, fuel injection takes place a little earlier and away from TDC. This makes an inadequate air compression to burn the fuel proficiently. Hence, advancing the IT elevates the fuel consumption and hence the BSFC at a particular load. Therefore, 20°BTDC may be considered as an optimum IT at lowest BSFC. At 20°, 23° and 28°BTDC, the average EGTs are 184 °C, 193 °C and 192 °C, respectively. For the POME run engine, the advancement and retardation of IT makes the EGT to drop by 1% and 5%, respectively. The IT of 20°BTDC is a favorable spot for maximum heat release and hence improves BSFC and BTHE. At no-load, the mean temperatures are found to be 128.6 °C, 135.1 °C and 130.94 °C, whereas at full-load, they are 249.3 °C, 264.5 °C and 262.2 °C.

sec.title: Effect of load
sec.p:
The effect of CR variations on cylinder pressure at 4.14 bar BMEP (100% load) for the ITs studied are shown in Figure 5(a) to (c). At this load, the maximum BTHE is observed irrespective of CR or IT. The average maximum pressure rise rate (MPRR) for POME test is around 6 bar per crank angle as opposed to 9 bar per crank angle for diesel. That means, POME provides a relatively quieter and smoother operation as compared to diesel and observed similarly at other loads too. This is because POME not only starts burning a little earlier than diesel, but also burns for a longer duration to give a smoother output. Figure 5(d) to (f) indicates a linear rise of PCP with the increase in load. For both POME and diesel, the average rise in PCP is found to be around 5%. It is seen that the peak PCP is obtained at full-load with CR = 18 for all the IT combinations. These PCP values are 76.1, 76.3 and 84.4 bar, respectively. Figure 6(a) to (c) shows that IDs vary inversely with respect to load for all the CR and IT studied. From no-load to full-load, the average IDs for POME are 18, 17, 16, 16, 15 and 14; whereas for diesel, they are 21, 20, 19, 19, 18 and 17. This is due to the higher BTHE of POME than diesel. The lower ID of POME is also clear from Figure 5(a) to (c). Figure 6(d) to (f) shows that POME starts releasing heat much prior to diesel as observed from the ID curves. The higher BTHE, and hence the lower ID, is a key fuel property that determines premixed combustion duration as observed by Benjumea et al.27 However, the peak NHRR point for POME is lower than diesel. This is due to a little lower LCV of POME than diesel. Similar kinds of trends have also been observed by Banapurmath and Tewari42 while working with Honge oil methyl ester. Figure 5.
Variation of cylinder pressure (100% engine load) with crank angle (a, b and c) and peak cylinder pressure with engine load (d, e and f) for different compression ratio and injection timing.
Figure 6.
Variation of ignition delay with engine load (a, b and c) and net heat-release rate (100% engine load) with crank angle (d, e and f) for different compression ratio and injection timing.

sec.title: Effect of compression ratio
sec.p: Figure 5(a) to (c) shows that with the increase in CR, the cylinder pressure at each crank angle increases gradually. As a result, the cylinder pressure curves spread more as seen from these plots. This is due to the reduction of cylinder volume with the increase in CR. Side-by-side, with the rise of CR, the air inside the cylinder gains more heat during compression stroke and the injected fuel starts burning instantly but uniformly. As a result, at higher CR, a smoother combustion is obtained for POME than diesel. At CR of 16, the clearance volume expands which lowers the heat of compression, thereby causing local and rough combustion for POME. Figure 5(d) to (f) presents the average PCPs of 55, 58 and 61 bar at CR of 16; whereas PCPs observed at 18 CR are 18 of 67, 69 and 75 bar for the three ITs of POME run engine. The average increase in PCP for POME with the increase in CR from 16 to17, 17 to 17.5 and 17.5 to 18 are 5%, 6% and 9%, respectively. With the rise in CR, the cylinder volume gets reduced, and this increases the temperature and pressure in compression stroke. As a result, the fuel burns more intensely and elevates the pressure further at TDC. This is also the reason behind the drop of ID for POME with the rise of CR (Figure 6). At higher CR, the warmer environment inside cylinder speeds up the onset of combustion thereby reducing the ID. The average IDs for POME at 16 CR are 15.33°, 17.67° and 18.33° crank angle (CA) where 13.17°, 14.67° and 16.33° CA of IDs are obtained at 18 CR. The average cut of IDs with the rise in CR from 16 to 17, 17 to 17.5 and 17.5 to 18 are 5%, 3% and 7%, respectively. The CR variation, from 16 to 18 affects NHRR of POME (Figure 6). The increase in CR results an early start of ignition for POME, which later reduces the premixed combustion phase. The effect is further prominent at full-load condition where the NHRR is high because of warmer environment. The reduction of the premixed combustion phase and the increase in the diffused combustion is similarly observed in literature for various blending of waste cooking oil with diesel as compared to lone diesel.43

sec.title: Effect of injection timing
sec.p: Figure 5(a) to (c) shows that IT advancement causes the fuel to start burning early and gets more time to burn completely. As a result, at higher IT, the P–θ curve spreads more and boosts further by the lower ID of POME. The similar trend is observed at other loads also. This phenomenon has a noticeable effect on the PCP curves as shown in Figure 5(d) to (f). For the four CRs studied, the average PCPs varied from 55, 59, 63 and 67 bar to 61, 65, 69 and 75 bar for 20°BTDC and 28°BTDC, respectively. The IT retardation and advancement causes the PCP to increase by 2% and 9%, respectively. During advancement, the larger combustion period allows the fuel to burn for a longer duration to give higher PCP. The IT advancement causes increase in ID for POME and vice versa (Figure 6). For the CRs studied, the average IDs obtained for IT of 20°BTDC are 15.33, 14.67, 14.33 and 13.17, whereas at 28°BTDC, these values are 18.33, 17.67, 16.83 and 16.33. The IT advancement causes an average rise of ID by about 6%, whereas retardation results an average drop of ID by about 12%. At retarded IT, POME spray takes place at a crank angle closest to the TDC. At that instant, the atmosphere in the cylinder is more pressurized and heated comparable to other ITs. This makes the burn prone POME to ignite faster, locally and globally inside the cylinder. Therefore, the retardation is found to have more effect on ID than advancement. Figure 6, however, shows that advancing the IT provides a rise in the peak NHRR points. It is also clear that the curves also get shifted towards the compression stroke as the IT advances. Though, at an advanced IT, the fuel burns for a longer duration and releases more heat, but it does not seem to increase BTHE as obtained at retardation as discussed in section ‘Effect of injection timing’. This is due to the higher BSFC at advancement as opposed to retardation. The fact is also ascertained from the findings of Devan and Mahalakshmi.44 The combustion analysis, therefore, demonstrates the setting of CR = 18 and IT = 20°BTDC to be the optimum among all the combinations.

sec.title: Effect of load
sec.p:
Figure 7(a) to (c) shows the average variation of CO emissions from no-load to full-load. The CO emissions for POME are 64, 45, 33, 25, 32 and 44 parts per million (ppm), whereas for diesel, they are found to be 120, 70, 56, 48, 58 and 95 ppm. An insufficient temperature at lower load region, and a richer mixture supplied at higher loads cause incomplete combustion and elevates CO emissions as described by Mahanta et al.45 The average drop of CO emission from diesel on the basis of load variation is 45%. As observed in Figure 7(d) to (f), the average CO2 variations with respect to load are found to be 1.4%, 2.0%, 2.4%, 3.0%, 3.7% and 4.5% for POME whereas these variations for diesel are 2.5%, 3.1%, 3.3%, 3.6%, 4.0% and 4.4%. At low to mid load regions, the CO2 emissions generated by POME are far lower than diesel emissions. However, at higher loads, high combustion temperatures cause more oxidation of carbons to produce higher CO2 emissions. POME produces overall 21% lower CO2 emission than diesel. Figure 8(a) to (c) explains the variations of NOX emissions with respect to load. From no-load to full-load conditions, the average NOX emissions obtained for the POME run engine are 24, 32, 43, 59, 78 and 93 ppm, as opposed to 24, 40, 49, 61, 76 and 92 ppm for the diesel engine. This increasing trend of NOX emission with respect to load is dependent on combustion temperature and is substantiated by EGT curves (Figure 3). At high load region, the increase in temperature accelerates the thermal NO formation.37 This is the reason behind the higher NOX emission for POME at higher load region. However, for all the ITs studied, the NOX emission for POME is lower than diesel by 6%. Figure 8(d) to (f) shows that the trends of HC emissions at lower and higher load regions vary with descending and ascending orders. For the POME run engine, the average HC emissions at no-load to full-load regions are 19, 14, 10, 8, 14 and 19 ppm; whereas for the diesel engine, the corresponding values are 30, 22, 17, 14, 15 and 19 ppm. At lower load regions, the combustion temperatures reach to a rather lower value to enable total combustion. However, at higher load regions, the mass of fuel supply increases to produce more power to take up the high load. Both of these facts are responsible for the release of unburnt HC.18 Figure 7.
Variation of carbon monoxide (a, b and c) and carbon dioxide (d, e and f) with engine for different compression ratio and injection timing.
Figure 8.
Variation of oxides of nitrogen (a, b and c) and hydrocarbon (d, e and f) with engine load for different compression ratio and injection timing.

sec.title: Effect of compression ratio
sec.p: The mean CO emissions for POME at CRs of 16, 17, 17.5 and 18 are 50, 41, 41 and 30 ppm (Figure 7). The rise in CR reduces the cylinder volume, which in turn, increases the combustion temperature. This accelerates the molecular oxygen formation, which reacts with CO. That is why an increase of CR from 16 to 18 results a drop in CO emission by 40%. The same cause attributes the surge in the CO2 emission with the increase in CR (Figure 7). The average CO2 emissions recorded are 2.6%, 2.7%, 3.0% and 3.1% (by volume) for all four CRs. The overall rise in CO2 emission is 19% with the increase of CR from 16 to 18. As observed in Figure 8(a) to (c), the average NOX emissions obtained at CR of 16, 17, 17.5 and 18 are 72, 57, 52 and 39 ppm. Hence, for the POME run engine, the rise in CR causes an overall reduction of NOX emission by 46%. At high CR, the pressure and temperature at the end of compression stroke and at the early stages of combustion increases. Alongside, the lower ID of POME causes the combustion to complete a little earlier. As a result, the combustion products become much cooler at the end of combustion as explained in the previous section and as seen from Figure 3. This fact slows down the NOX formation. For POME, an increase in CR causes a reduction in NOX emission. As observed in Figure 8(d) to (f), the average HC emissions obtained are 17, 15, 14 and 10 ppm for POME. Thus, HC emission drops by 40% via increasing the CR from 16 to 18. The higher temperature and pressure in the compression stroke coupled with lower ID cause faster burning of POME.

sec.title: Effect of injection timing
sec.p: The CO emission is the result of incomplete combustion of fuels, and hence, it depends on BSFC. For POME run engine, retarding and advancing the IT shows a fall of 15% and 26% in CO emission, respectively (Figure 7). The results are clear from the BSFC values obtained at different ITs as elaborated in section ‘Effect of injection timing’.46 Lower the BSFC, lower will be the mass of unburnt fuel particles and hence lesser will be the chances of CO emission. The results show that advancement and retardation of IT cuts the CO2 emission by 13% and 16%, respectively (Figure 7). The NOX emission study shows that IT advancement causes a rise in NOX emission by 17% and 39% (Figure 8). The IT advancement increases PCP, which in turn, increases the peak temperature too as detailed in subsection ‘Effect of injection timing’ (under ‘Combustion analysis’ section).37 This is the reason behind the NOX increase with IT advancement. The HC emission (Figure 8) in the exhaust gas is the result of the partly burnt fuel particles. The IT advancement and retardation results in an average drop of HC emissions by 18% and 40%, respectively. The advancement causes an early start of combustion, and the charge being compressed as the piston moves to TDC, has relatively higher temperatures. Thus, it can easily be observed that advancement rises the average temperature by 5%. This causes a reduction in the flame quenching layer thickness, leading to a lower HC emission.47

sec.title: Uncertainty analysis
sec.p: The sequential perturbation technique48 is followed to obtain the uncertainties of independent and performance parameters. Some of these are air flow rate (1.1%), liquid fuel flow rate (0.1 %), engine load (0.1%), engine speed (1.3%), temperature (1.0%), lower heating value of fuel (1%), etc. On the basis of these, the calculated accuracy of the performance and combustion studies is found within ± 3.6%. However, the accuracy of the emissions is found to be within ± 2.3%.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Being a fuel of different origin than fossil diesel, POME is incapable of reproducing the performance, obtained from an engine tailor-made for diesel. Therefore, the aim of this study was to optimize a set of design and operational parameters namely, load, CR and IT conditions for a 100% POME run diesel engine. At higher loads, BTHEs of POME run engine is slightly lower than that of diesel engine. For a constant IT, an increase in CR increases the BTHE and lowers the BSFC. However, the collective variation of CR and IT shows that the peak values of BTHEs occur at CR of 17.5 and 18 at 20°BTDC. For the POME run engine, IT advancement does not increase BTHE to an extent as obtained by retardation. This is because BSFC is found to cut substantially during IT retardation instead of advancing. EGT increases linearly with the increase of load. At higher CRs, the POME runs more smoothly than diesel. The most significant finding of this study is the decrease of ID for POME with respect to diesel. Because of faster burning nature of POME, the engine at CR = 18 and IT = 20°BTDC shows a drop of ID by 31%. Further, at 20°BTDC, the retarded injection and ignition of fuel drive the NHRR curves to approach near to TDC. This results in an increase in heat release which ends up with largest BTHE.

The POME causes an average CO reduction of 45% than diesel on the basis of load variation. However, the rise in CR from 16 to 18 causes an increase in CO2 emission by 19%. This is because, at CR = 18, the high pressure and temperature at the primary phases of combustion causes the POME to burn more efficiently. It is also observed that, IT retardation cuts both CO and CO2 owing to the fall of BSFC. The increase in CR from 16 to 18 causes an overall drop of NOX emission by 46%. Although a rise in CR increases pressure and temperature at the early stages of combustion, yet, combustion starts and completes early. This causes the exhaust gas to cool down thereby reducing the NOX emission. The increase in CR from 16 to 18 causes a fall of HC emission by 40%. The same reason is responsible for CO emission too.

The present investigation reveals that POME can run efficiently in a diesel engine. Higher CR and retarded IT boosted with its inbuilt properties causes ample reduction of harmful emissions. However, there are enough scopes to improve the engine performances. For example, the higher fuel consumption as observed in the present investigation is confronted by applying fuel modification techniques, namely emulsification, use of additives, etc. to make POME as an attractive alternative renewable fuel.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
